Ubuntu only applies Patch-Updates so it will not be on the same version as upstream.

Take CVE-2019-17134/OSSA-2019-005 as example, it states 4.1.0 as the next stable release for Stein that has the fix. However Ubuntu does not supply this version has still 4.0.0 locked with a patch-update to include the fix versioned as 4.0.0-0ubuntu1.2~cloud.

So Building an image with Octavia's diskimage-create.sh to version 4.1.0 will be incompatible with Ubuntu's packages at version 4.0.0-* as the Amphora Agent does not implement 0.5 api anymore and the Octavia Worker does not use 1.0 api yet.

And in reverse, building an image tagged 4.0.0 to match Ubuntu's packages would leave the Operator vulnerable to CVE-2019-17134/OSSA-2019-005 but believing it is not as per Ubuntu Advisory mentioning 4.0.0-* versions.

This is a very specific example but this shows the general trend that Ubuntu is doing when it comes to patching.

As Amphora Images should be matching the version of the Octavia Worker, it is therefore advisable to use Ubuntu's retrofit utility to build matching Images.

I agree that the tool is very unknown and to be honest I've just learned of it yesterday from Ubuntu Staff when asked how to test their patches...

nit: It might be nice to have a note that explains what "octavia-diskimage-retrofit" does. We use diskimage-builder normally, so I'm not sure what this is for or what it does.

It's ubuntu's own DIB variant which uses ubuntu-packages instead of git-source as ubuntu doesnt do version updates for their packages but only patch-level updates. This is required for ubuntu to avoid incompatibility and vulnerabilities (see my previous comment about this)

Hmm, well, DIB supports using packages instead of git-source installs. The CentOS/RHEL DIB build uses packages in the main DIB.
Maybe you could look at updating the DIB elements to also use packages in the future.

If you want to update DIB feel free - I think that it would be out of scope for this change to be honest.

Regardless, currently retrofit is the way Ubuntu creates amphorae internally and does their own QA. I think we should recommend Ubuntu's tools to ensure that it actually works.

Ubuntu's retrofit tool incorporates the UCA repos which DIB doesn't know how to handle/add afaik.

As it stands today, retrofit is the only way to create an ubuntu amphora that is on par with the controller versions and functional.

Ubuntu really needs an equivalent of RDO/-trunk because this cherry-pick patch updates is an absolute nightmware to deal with as an Operator.

I 100% agree this is out of scope for this patch. DIB does use the UCA in some cases and it would be easy in elements to do so as well.

This is how I have it solved:
# cat /etc/systemd/network/o-hm0.network 
[Match]
Name=o-hm0

[Network]
DHCP=yes

# cat /etc/systemd/system/octavia-interface.service 
[Unit]
Description=Octavia Interface Creator
Requires=neutron-linuxbridge-agent.service
After=neutron-linuxbridge-agent.service

[Service]
Type=oneshot
RemainAfterExit=true
ExecStart=/opt/octavia-interface.sh start
ExecStop=/opt/octavia-interface.sh stop

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

# cat /opt/octavia-interface.sh 
#!/bin/bash

set -ex

MAC="fa:16:3e:36:6e:d5"
BRNAME="brq74337d8c-54"

if [ "$1" == "start" ]; then
 ip link add o-hm0 type veth peer name o-bhm0
 brctl addif $BRNAME o-bhm0
 ip link set o-bhm0 up
 ip link set dev o-hm0 address $MAC
 ip link set o-hm0 up
 iptables -I INPUT -i o-hm0 -p udp --dport 5555 -j ACCEPT
elif [ "$1" == "stop" ]; then
 ip link del o-hm0
else
 brctl show $BRNAME
 ip a s dev o-hm0
fi

You need to substitute linuxbridge-agent with ovf if needed and ofc the mac/br variables in the script

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/lbaa.message: this should be a different try at line 382, right?

That will be caught in 396, like before. utils.get_subnet_cidr can cause os_exc exception. If we didn't change anything in utils module, than both exceptions would be caught by the NeutronClientException whatever the reason. Eventually, we exchange the NeutronClientException to SDKException, unless you want to catch both of the exceptions separately.

> my point here is that worker_subnet_id is only used at lines 379/381, so, this message is targetting that, which I assume it should be a try/catch for lines 382-391. 

os_exc.ResourceNotFound will only raise on utils.get_subnet_cidr failure, since only this function was converted to openstacksdk at this point. So if we enclose with try:except lines 382-391 for this exception, it's not going to help, because that is still neutron client call.

We can enclose with try:except line 381:

    try:
        worker_subnet_cidr = utils.get_subnet_cidr(worker_subnet_id)
    except os_exc.ResourceNotFound:
        LOG.exception(…)

to narrow down the exception, if that's the point.

> Then, of course we still need to have the except at line 396 catching the NeutronClientException for both lines 365 and 382.

Right.
Ack. We don't want to create security group without worker_subnet_cidr anyway.
Right, this try/except should be on line 381, and perhaps also including 382-390 ass this neutron.create_security_group_rule will also go away soon

my point here is that worker_subnet_id is only used at lines 379/381, so, this message is targetting that, which I assume it should be a try/catch for lines 382-391. Then, of course we still need to have the except at line 396 catching the NeutronClientException for both lines 365 and 382.

nailgun/nailgun/db/migration/alembic_mig.message: We already have dns_nameservers column in the networking_configs table. It has JSON type. Why we are changing DB scheme instead of changing dns_nameservers structure?

"dns_nameservers" is a column where list of an IP addresses of upstream DNS servers is stored. "dns_domain" should be a column where DNS domain for a cluster should be stored. I think these entities are pretty different.
In the /etc/fuel/astute.yaml these settings are stored is such way:
"DNS_DOMAIN": "domain.tld"
"DNS_SEARCH": "domain.tld"
"DNS_UPSTREAM": "8.8.8.8"
That's why I decided to place DNS domain to another column.

Don't use 'settings' module in Alembic migrations. The default value may change in one of future release, hence leading to not persistend result. Or evern worse, what the setting will be renamed one day? This migration start failing.

It's a common practice to hardcode values inside migration files.

nailgun/nailgun/task/manager.py.message:
didn't get it. I think that priorities only makes sense among siblings, not between 'parent' and 'child'.
For instance a depends on b and c. The order is only defined by priorities of b and c, nothing else.
The issue is caused by separation of the graphs for the deployment and resetup. Inside each graph priorities are correct, but after graphs merge they can be broken.

I wonder, do we trigger child (required) tasks in case of resetup? I thought these tasks are ones with flag:

   reexecute_on: [deploy_changes]

hence, only those tasks with flag are affected. No child.
No, we wouldn't trigger on resetup child task withou flag 'reexecute_on': ['deploy_changes']. I'll rephrase comment to make it clear.

I think it might be quite useful to check for `is not None`:

  if p is not None

in case `p` is `0`, because `0` is a valid priority but will be ignored by `if p` condition.

when second nodes is created, nailgun searches for de:ad:be:ef:00:01 in nodes table mac field, does not find it, and starts search with all macs in meta against node_nic_interfaces table through all macs there. This fix ensures that non-unique macs defined in settings are ignored in such search. This test relies on the fix to create two nodes with identical non-PXE macs

It would be better to have test that returns 409 in some case (i.e., when macs are not in NON_UNIQUE_MACS). 
It will show difference more clearly.

IMO, it would be helpful to have test for PUT as well (to not make API tests rely on knowledge of validator internals).

specs/9.0/add-memcache-loadbalancer.rst.message: Is there a twemproxy puppet module?  If not are we going to have to write one and write tests?
Should we evaluate if switching to something like redis might also address the problem?

We can switch to redis, but it won't solve our current main problem with memcached - when one node is dead, service can't understand it for a long time. Twemproxy can work like haproxy - talk with backend and deactivate it fast, when it is dead.
Is there any security items around auth for twemproxy?  Memcache is inherently insecure, should we look into an alternative or does this provide us anything extra?
Twemproxy is just a proxy. It supports what memcache supports, so no auth. If we will switch to Redis - twemproxy supports it too, with auth. But as I know, we okay with memcached w/o auth right now.

Where does this problem come from? is it an issue with the memcache module in python not properly handling connection failures to memcache? Because i thought that when you configure multiple servers, it hashes which server to use based on the memcache key and if one dies then it should just automatically move on to a different server. This seems like we're either configuring the existing memcache wrong or a problem in the memcache driver we're using.
Problem is in the mech keystone used for memcache. It just takes too long time to understand that some of servers is dead.

This seems like we're adding in a single point of failure because if twemproxy craps out we've lost all caching... How are we going to ensure that twemproxy is always running? Will we be putting it into pacemaker?
We put respawn in twemproxy init file, so system will look on it.

for completeness, you could mention 2 other alternative solutions that have been discussed on the operators mailing list lately:

- mcrouter [0]
- memcached with the repcached patches [1]

[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2015-December/009220.html
[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2015-December/009186.html
